newsobjects.title: Using ‘baby’ teeth to predict hominin tooth size
newsobjects.desc: A new study by an international team including ASU researchers Gary Schwartz, Susanne Daly, and Kierstin Catlett, combined tools from embryology, comparative anatomy and computational biology to reveal that a single embryonic rule has regulated hominin tooth size.

newsobjects.title: Drilling into the climate-human evolutionary connection
Monkeying around with pals
newsobjects.desc: Joan Silk studiesfemale baboons and how they determine who is friendly and who is not.

lectureobjects.name: Curtis Marean PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Curtis Marean conducts field research in South Africa and leads a large international transdisciplinary team of scientists investigating the relationships between climate and environmental change in the origin of modern humans. He uses zooarchaeological methods to investigate the significance of large mammals as dietary resources for early humans and early technologies, like stone tools, which may have been used as weapons.
lectureobjects.title: Associate Director, Institute of Human Origins\nFoundation Professor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Thomas Morgan PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Tom Morgan’s research focuses on how humans possess both uniquely complex cognition and uniquely complex culture. His goal is to explain the former, by integrating the latter into an evolutionary framework. His work involves two major themes: the nature and evolution of the psychological mechanisms that support culture, and evolutionary models and large-scale experiments to understand how culture changes the evolutionary process offering novel explanations for how humans came to be.
lectureobjects.title: Research Affiliate, Institute of Human Origins\nAssistant Professor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Gary Schwartz PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Gary Schwartz analyzes the growth and development of living and fossil primates to understand the evolution of human life history. He reconstructs when, where, and how the unique elements of modern human growth first evolved. He is part of a transdisciplinary team working in South Africa to recover fossil and lithic remains associated with the origin of the genus Homo at around two million years ago.
lectureobjects.title: Research Associate, Institute of Human Origins\nAssociate Professor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Charles Perreault PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Charles Perreault studies the origins of culture and the coevolution of genes and culture. His main research goal is to better understand how archaeological data can contribute to cultural evolution theory, much in the same way that paleontology interacts with genetics theory, particularly in how cultural evolution processes unfold at both the micro- and the macro-scale, and how one can transit between these two different observational scales.
lectureobjects.title: Research Affiliate, Institute of Human Origins\nAssistant Professor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Christopher Campisano PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Chris Campisano uses a variety of geological field and analytical methods to investigate the influence of environmental change on terrestrial landscapes and hominin evolution in Africa. His research contributes to understanding how early hominins responded and adapted to these changes in comparison to other animals across time and space.
lectureobjects.title: Research Associate, Institute of Human Origins\nAssistant Professor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Ian Gilby PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Ian Gilby’s research lies at the interface of behavioral ecology and evolutionary anthropology. The broad goal of his research program is to understand the roots of human cooperation using primate behavioral ecology. To date, his work has focused on hunting, meat sharing, and social bonds among wild chimpanzees in Gombe National Park (Tanzania) and Kibale National Park (Uganda).
lectureobjects.title: Research Affiliate, Institute of Human Origins\nAssistant Professor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Donald C. Johanson PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Donald Johanson is the discoverer of the fossil hominin, Australopithecus afarensis, popularly known as “Lucy,” in the Hadar region of Ethiopia in 1974. He has led field explorations in Ethiopia, Tanzania, and the Middle East and is the founder of the Institute of Human Origins.
lectureobjects.title: Founding Director, Institute of Human Origins\nProfessor and Virginia M Ullman Chair in Human Origins\nSchool of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Kim Hill PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Kim Hill studies the evolutionary ecology of hunter-gatherer populations, with a focus on foraging theory, food sharing, life-history theory, cooperation, social structure, and cultural transmission. He has carried out field research in Paraguay, Peru, Venezuela, and Panama and is currently studying marine coastal foraging patterns in southern Africa and the Philippines and its importance in the expansion of Homo sapiens out of Africa.
lectureobjects.title: Research Associate, Institute of Human Origins\nProfessor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Sarah Mathew PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Sarah Mathew is interested in the evolution of human ultra-sociality and the role of culture in enabling it. She is particularly interested in how humans evolved to cooperate on extremely large scales that can include millions of people and how this ties with the origins of norms, moral sentiments, and prosocial preferences.
lectureobjects.title: Research Affiliate, Institute of Human Origins\nAssistant Professor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change\nCarnegie Fellow

lectureobjects.name: William H. Kimbel PhD
lectureobjects.bio: William Kimbel carries out field research recovering the fossil record of Pliocene-Pleistocene hominins in Ethiopia. He conducts comparative analyses of the early hominin skeletal evidence from across Africa to understand spatiotemporal patterns of diversity and their relationship to the emergence of key adaptations in the evolution of Australopithecus and Homo.
lectureobjects.title: Director, Institute of Human Origins\nVirginia M Ullman Professor of Natural History and the Environment\nSchool of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Kaye Reed PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Kaye Reed performs field research in Ethiopia to elucidate paleoenvironmental effects on hominin evolution greater than 2.9 million years ago, and in South Africa, where the search for fossil material around one- to two-million years ago contributes to understanding hominin landscape use. She studies community ecology to understand the socioecological context of hominin evolution and the interactions among living primate groups.
lectureobjects.title: Research Associate, Institute of Human Origins\nDirector and President’s Professor\nSchool of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Kevin Langergraber PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Most of Kevin Langergraber’s research focuses on the exceptionally large Ngogo chimpanzee community, which contains about 200 individually recognized and named chimpanzees. His research combines long-term behavioral observations and demographic data with genetic data derived from noninvasively collected fecal samples to answer questions about the evolution of chimpanzees and humans.
lectureobjects.title: Research Affiliate, Institute of Human Origins\nAssistant Professor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Erich Fisher PhD
lectureobjects.bio:
Erich Fisher is a research scientist with the Institute of Human Origins at Arizona State University. He is interested in the origins of modern humans and archaeoinformatic methodologies to analyze and archive archaeological sites and assemblages.
Erich has field experience across the Horn of Africa, East Africa, South Africa, Arabia, and Mesoamerica, and he currently collaborates on six international research projects. Erich joined ASU in 2008 after finishing his Fulbright-sponsored PhD research on stone tool technological change in southern Ethiopia. He received his PhD from the University of Florida in 2010 and has since held postdoctoral and faculty research positions at ASU.
lectureobjects.title: Assistant Research Scientist

lectureobjects.name: Melissa Wilson Sayres PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Melissa Wilson Sayres is a computational biologist whose main research interests include sex-biased biology. She studies the evolution of sex chromosomes (X and Y in mammals), why mutation rates differ between males and females, and how changes in population history affect the sex chromosomes differently than the non-sex chromosomes. Wilson Sayres is also active in public science engagement and outreach.
lectureobjects.title: Research Affiliate, Institute of Human Origins\nAssistant Professor, School of Life Sciences

lectureobjects.name: Anne Stone PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Anne Stone’s main area of interest is anthropological genetics. In particular, she works on applications of population genetics to questions concerning the origins, population history and evolution of humans and the great apes. At present, her research examines the biological history of Native Americans, both ancient and modern, with a current focus on native Peruvian populations and is also interested in the evolution and genetic diversity of primates, particularly the genus Pan, which includes chimpanzees and bonobos.
lectureobjects.title: Research Affiliate, Institute of Human Origins\nRegents’ Professor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Joan Silk PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Joan Silk studies the evolution of cooperation in comparative perspective. She studies the form and function of social relationships in wild baboons, in which cooperation is largely based on kinship and reciprocity. She performs experiments to assess altruistic preferences in chimpanzees and the development of altruistic preferences in children across a range of human cultures.
lectureobjects.title: Research Affiliate, Institute of Human Origins\nProfessor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change

lectureobjects.name: Robert Boyd PhD
lectureobjects.bio: Rob Boyd conducts research on the evolutionary psychology of the mechanisms that gave rise to, and continue to shape, human culture. He is particularly concerned with how these mechanisms interact with population dynamic processes to generate human cultural variation. His work combines mathematical theory and empirical field research.
lectureobjects.title: Research Affiliate, Institute of Human Origins\nOrigins Professor, School of Human Evolution and Social Change

galleryobjects.title: Looking from inside the cave out to the ocean.
International teams drilled in five locations in Africa near important human origins discovery sites.
Long cores will be analyzed over deep time to consider how human ancestors cope with climate change.
Excavations in the cave have uncovered over 50,000 years of human habitation including shells, stone tools, and evidence of fire activity.
Understanding primate behavior can help researchers understand how early hominins interacted with each other and their environment.
Camp Hadar, Ethiopia, where scientists set up for the field season.
Finding fossils among rocks and dirt is a tedious, but potentially rewarding, experience
Welcome to the IHO Image Gallery
“Lucy” is the popular name for the 3.2-million-year-old fossil skeleton—Australopithecus afarensis—discovered by Donald Johanson in Hadar, Ethiopia, in 1974.

featureobjects.title: Research shows humans thrived through Toba super-volcanic eruption
featureobjects.desc:
Super-volcano Mt. Toba eruption in Indonesia had global effects. IHO researcher Curtis Marean has been studying an archaeological site at the southern tip of South Africa where there is evidence of glass shards from the eruption and where humans took refuge during glacial periods, from around 195,000 to 130,000 years ago and again between 74,000 and 60,000 years ago. \n
The research was covered widely in the scientific and popular media with coverage in The New York Times (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/12/science/toba-supervolcano-supereruption.html) and Science Magazine (http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2018/03/how-ancient-humans-survived-global-volcanic-winter-massive-eruption).

imagesarray.title: Bill Kimbel leads fieldwork in Hadar, Ethiopia, to train the next generation of paleoanthropologists.
Some learning techniques have to be experienced firsthand—in the field, Kimbel explains how to identify fossil material from surrounding rock and dirt.
In 2013, Neil Shubin brought a film production company to Hadar to feature IHO’s research in the “Your Inner Fish” series for PBS. Featured are Kimbel, Shubin, and Donald Johanson.

A plaque has been erected identifying the site of the Lucy discovery—now more than 40 years ago. Featured are IHO Executive Board members Peter and Carol Saucier, with Johanson on an IHO trip to Ethiopia in 2012.
Johanson, here with the complete Lucy fossil skeleton, c.1975.

IHO Executive Board members Mrs. Kenneth Leventhal, Laura Roskind, Don Johanson, Bobby Kimbel, Joan Travis, and Herb Roskind at the Bower’s Museum in California with the original “Lucy” fossil bones on its final U.S. museum visit in 2014 before returning to the National Museum of Ethiopia.
Johanson at the Nobel Symposium in 1978 announcing a new species—Australopithecus afarensis.
Don Johanson discovered the fossil known as “Lucy” in Hadar, Ethiopia, in 1974. Here, he is laying out the bones in the field.
Curtis Marean’s research is focused on the archaeological remains of early modern humans in caves at the tip of South Africa in Mossel Bay.
Students learn the careful excavation techniques required to ensure artifacts are preserved and recorded properly.
Marean is a leader in digital mapping techniques to pinpoint and identify where artifacts are uncovered during excavation.
The research site hosts a variety of international scientists but is also the classroom for students from ASU and around the world to learn about archaeology and paleontology.
Excavations have uncovered over 50,000 years of human habitation in these caves.
Students learn the careful excavation techniques required to ensure artifacts are preserved and recorded properly.
Rob Boyd’s fieldwork takes him to the islands of Fiji to understand how culture influences human behavior.
Boyd camping among the rocks.
Boyd spends time out of the classroom rock climbing and hiking.
Chris Campisano shares his training as a geologist with students in the field in Hadar, Ethiopia.
The scientists hope to analyze the climate across several million years to understand how climate change may correlate with how our human ancestors evolved and changed.
Campisano works late into the night at the Hadar field site getting ready for the next day’s field research.
Campisano is one of the lead scientists on a $10 million project that drilled deep-core samples at five sites in Kenya and Ethiopia close to major hominin discovery sites.
Ian Gilby is a codirector of the long-term Gombe chimpanzee database of the Jane Goodall Institute in Tanzania.
Gilby spends weeks in the forest observing and recording how particular male hunters influence the entire group’s hunting behavior.
Gilby’s research focuses on male chimpanzee cooperation and social bonds.
Hill at a community gathering with the Ache, a group in Paraguay that he has worked with for many years.
Hill listens to a group of men before they leave for a hunt.
Kim Hill has spent many research years living with indigenous hunter-gatherer communities in South America.
Kevin Langergraber follows groups of chimpanzees to observe their hunting and meat-sharing behaviors.
Langergraber is co-director of the Ngogo Chimpanzee Project. Here, he expertly captures many of his subjects in his camera lense—this is Abrams.
Sarah Mathew’s research focuses on evolution and human behavior, cooperation, and warfare.
Tom Morgan spends his time outside of the classroom hiking and rock climbing.
Perreault, along with archaeologists from Mongolia, excavated potential sites in Darkhad Valley of northern Mongolia in search of a newly discovered ancient hominin species called Denisovans.
Charles Perreault’s research site is at cave sites in the hills of Mongolia where he is looking for evidence of the Denisovans.
Reed was co-leader of the team that found a jawbone dated to 2.8 million years ago, about 400,000 years earlier than previously known fossils of Homo.
Reed’s research is focused on understanding the environment—the plant and animal life—that ancient human ancestors lived in.
Kaye Reed was named director of the School of Human Evolution and Social Change in 2016 and ASU President’s Professor in 2014. Here, President Crow presents Reed with the award.
Schwartz has conducted field research in South Africa and Ethiopia.
Developing teeth grow layers, similar to rings on a tree, which tell the story of an individual’s life history.
Gary Schwartz’s research analyzes modern human and ancient human ancestors’ and primate teeth to provide clues to what our ancestors ate and how they developed and grew over their life histories.
Joan Silk is the coauthor of The Evolution of Primate Societies.
Silk has spent many field seasons following and understanding wild baboons in the field.
Silk’s research focuses on the prosocial behaviors of baboons.
Anne Stone runs the "Stone Lab" at ASU, which has a central focus of anthropological genetics.
In the lab, undergraduate and graduate students learn cross-disciplinary research in bioarchaeological, molecular genetic, population genetic, and genomic analyses.
